description.narrative: Omprogrammerade medel för att lindra konsekvenserna av covid-19 Makedonien har åtagit sig att arbeta för en stärkt jämställdhet genom dels internationella åtaganden och dels nationella policies och planer. I Makedonien har en reform av den offentliga finansiella styrningen inletts där man bl.a vill införa programbaserad budgetering. Man önskar även införliva en jämställdhetsintegrerad budgetprocess. Det betyder att nationella och lokala budgetar formuleras, planeras, genomförs och utvärderas med hänsyn till de olika behov män, kvinnor, pojkar och flickor har samt vilka effekter som budgeten ger för dessa olika grupper. Reformen berör både central och kommunal nivå. UN Women har sedan tidigare arbetat med jämställdhetsintegrering i budgetprocesser, i Makedonien och i ett 70-tal andra länder. I föreliggande programförslag i Makedonien medverkar, förutom berörda stats- och kommuntjänstemän, även parlamentariker och kommunpolitiker samt civilsamhällesorganisationer. Sida, tillsammans med schweiziska SDC, stödjer detta arbete under perioden 2018-2021 med ett belopp om totalt 11,7 miljoner SEK.

Reprogrammed funds to mitigate the impact of COVID-19 Macedonia has made commitments to work for improved gender equality by signing international conventions and enacting national laws and policies. An ongoing reform of the public financial management system includes an initative to introduce and institutionalise gender responsive budgeting (GRB). This means that national and local budgets are formulated, planned, executed and evaluated with consideration to the needs of men, women, boys and girls, and that the effects budgets bring are analysed with reference ot these groups. The reform concerns both central and municipal level. UN Women has been involved in GRB work both in Macedonia and in around 70 other countries in the world. The programme in Macedonia involves civil servants both at central and local level, parliamentarians, local politicians and civil society organisations. Sida, together with Swiss SDC, supports the implementation of the programme with 11.7 million SEK during the period 2018-2021.

The project Promoting Gender Responsive Policies and Budgets: Towards Transparent, Inclusive and Accountable Governance in FYR of Macedonia has an overall objective “To improve women’s lives and support the inclusion of the most vulnerable groups through systematic and sustainable integration of gender perspective at all stages of national and local policy-making and budgeting processes.” To contribute to the achievement of the overall goal, the project will work towards achieving the following two outcomes: - The Government’s public finance management and the strategic planning processes are improved to respond to the different needs of women and men as a result of effective application of gender responsive budgeting - Civil society organizations, women, including the most vulnerable actively participate in planning and decision-making mechanisms, and their priorities are fully reflected in public policies and budgets. The theory of change of the proposed intervention is as follows: IF (1) national and local institutions formulate, implement and monitor evidence-based policies and budgets which fully reflect gender equality commitments; (2) Members of Parliament and gender advocates demand accountability to GEWE commitments; (3) Women, including the most vulnerable, voice their needs and participate in local planning and decision-making; THEN more women, including the most vulnerable, will influence the development of and benefit from gender responsive policies and budgets; BECAUSE the capacities of national and local institutions are increased, accountability mechanisms are strenghtened and women's needs and concerns are fully taken into consideration.

description.narrative: Achieving gender equality (GE) remains one of the priorities of the Government of North Macedonia. During the period the project continued with intensive implementation of project activities achieving the expected results, upgraded with established unexpected new partnerships . The unexpected partnerships include the established partnership with the State Audit Office, the Faculty of Agricultural Sciences and Food, and extended cooperation on local level with10 new municipalities. The number of directly supported municipalities has reached 31 municipalities. In 2021, the Project continued to support key strategic and normative processes aimed at advancing GE : - Including Gender responsive budgeting (GRB) as one of the key budget principles in the Organic Budget Law (OBL). The Law is waiting to be put on Parliament's Agenda for discussion; - Preparation of a gender sensitive citizens budget has been initiated in 2021 by the Ministry of finance. - Legal obligation is established for all budget users to submit data related to GRB when submitting the budget request to the Ministry of finance. However, not all institutions submit such data, due to lack of knowledge for completing the required documents. Organizing trainings for the public administration focused on identifying gender responsive programs and developing gender indicators is to be intensified with putting into function the Resource Center for Gender Responsive Policymaking and Budgeting, that was officially launched on 3rd March 2022. - An online platform for the Resource Center is being developed. - Support is provided to preparation of the National Strategy for GE (2021-2026) and to the Strategy for Agriculture and Rural Development (2021-2027). The work at local level, is primarily focusing on: - Support to 31 municipalities to apply GRB in their policymaking and budgetary processes; - Development of new local strategies for gender equality; - Mainstreaming gender in the Regional Development Strategy (2021-2031); - Supporting measures for socio-economic empowerment of women in 12 municipalities, focusing on vulnerable groups through a series of trainings. - Moreover, UN Women cooperates with two partner organizations that provide support to women through 13 local civil society organizations. About 3,300 women were involved in outreach initiatives and 36 recommendations have been submitted by women to the municipalities which resulted in specific budget allocations at local level. - Rural women have been recognized as being one of the most disadvantaged population groups in society, both in terms of access to land, services and finances as well as in regards to the double burden of unpaid care work and absence from the labor market. As a result of the collaborative effort of UN Women, the Ministry for Agriculture, Forestry and Water Economy (MAFWE), Academia and civil society organizations that represent the needs of rural women, the rural women for the first time have been given the opportunity to apply for financial support aimed at boosting the agricultural production and improving their livelihood. Resulting from the above, a new support measure - Measure 115 was defined and introduced into the budget of MAFWE, under the state Program for financial support for rural development, which was intended for women agricultural producers. During 2021, 250 women received financial support in amount of 180,000 MKD (3000 EUR) per beneficiary to realize their business investments. The women benefiting this support are applying to an annual call for proposals which is published and managed by MAFWE. UN Women reports that this support measure is planned to continue in 2022, with increased budget of 360,000 MKD per beneficiary. The end target of the ministry is to reach 600,000 MKD per beneficiary in the coming years. Itt is to boost agricultural production and small farms development in the rural areas. - The unexpected result achieved by the extended cooperation with the State Audit Office (SAO) provides for improved implementation, strong integration of GRB into the system, and sustainability of GE obligations in line with the national laws and policies. A Memorandum of Understanding is signed between SAO and UN Women, that resulted with several successful activities implemented during 2021 including: capacity building of 90 employees at SAO on gender mainstreaming and gender-responsive budgeting, and for conducting gender audits. The first ever gender performance audit has been rolled out by the SAO, which is in a final stage, and the conclusions and recommendations are expected to be published soon.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
